choices.text: Pre-invasive diagnostic test

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant woman of 13 weeks gestation age informs about accidental exposure to radiation during chest X-ray at 7 weeks of gestation. What should be the next step advised to her?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Continue pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Most diagnostic radiographic procedures are associated with minimal fetal risk and hence pregnancy can be continued in the case given

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B: Termination of pregnancy is not required as the exposure of radiation in a chest X Ray is negligible and will not cause fetal harm
  • Option C: Pre-invasive diagnostic test: This is not indicated unless a screening test is positive
  • Option D: Chromosome screening: Is indicated as usual in all pregnant women and not specifically for women with a Chest X Ray exposure. Also, this is done routinely between 11-14 weeks (combined screening)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ionizing radiation: Max energy is in X rays and gamma rays
  • Can cause structural change in DNA – risk of
    • Abortion
    • Malformations
    • Fetal growth restriction
    • Increased incidence of childhood cancers
       
  • NOAEL (No observed adverse effect level): 0.05 Gy; Below this level: No Effects on Pregnancy (To reach this level, about 500 Chest X Rays are required.
  • Chest Xray: < 0.0001 Gy / view
  • IVP: increased exposure: 7 - 14 mGy
  • Increased exposure with CT scans
  • USG – safe
  • MRI – safe (does not use ionizing radiation)
  • Gadolinium (contrast) in MRI is contraindicated.

 

Ref: ACOG Committee Opinion on Guidelines for Diagnostic Imaging During Pregnancy and Lactation 2017

choices.text: Intra-decidual sign is negative
It is eccentric in position
Peripheral vascularity is seen
Yolk sac is seen at 5.5 weeks

questions.text: All are features of a true sac except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Intra-decidual sign is negative

 

Explanation:

 

  • Intra-decidual sign is seen in a true sac

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B: A true sac is eccentric in position
  • Option C: Peripheral vascularity is seen in a true gestational sac
  • Option D: Yolk sac is seen at 5.5 weeks in a TVS

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page No 186, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Early intra-uterine pregnancy
Intra-uterine pseudo gestational sac
Tubal ectopic pregnancy

questions.text: Double Decidual Sac sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Early Intra – uterine pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

Double decidual sac sign is seen in an intra-uterine pregnancy.

 

Other Options

 

  • Option B: An intra-uterine pseudo sac is seen usually in an ectopic pregnancy, It is fluid collection in the uterus
  • Option C: Tubal ectopic pregnancy: in this a double decidual sac sign wont be seen. USG signs of a tubal pregnancy include bagel sign, blob sign and ring of fire sign
  • Option D: In Molar pregnancy, the characteristic sign seen is the snowstorm appearance

 

Educational Objective:

 

Double Decidual sac sign:

 

  • Is a useful feature on early pregnancy ultrasound to confirm an early intrauterine pregnancy (IUP) 
  • Especially useful when the yolk sac or embryo is still not visualized.
  • It consists of the decidua parietalis (lining the uterine cavity) and decidua capsularis (lining the gestational sac)
  • It is seen as two concentric rings surrounding an anechoic gestational sac.
  • Where the two adhere is the decidua basalis, and is the site of future placental formation.

 

 

Another sign of an intra-uterine pregnancy is the intra-decidual sign.

 

Ref: Page no 159, William’s Obstetrics

questions.text: Which of the following abnormalities can be diagnosed in the 1sttrimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anencephaly

 

Anencephaly can be detected by USG as early as 11 weeks. 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B: Encephalocele: It is a sac like protrusion of the brain and the membranes covering it through a opening in the skull.
  • Option C: Meningocele: It is a sac like protrusion of the meninges without neural tissue due to defects in posterior elements of the spine (Spina Bifida).
  • Option D: Microcephaly: when the baby’s head is significantly smaller than expected due to abnormal brain development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Most anomalies are detected in the 2nd trimester.
  • The anomalies that can be detected in the 1st trimester (11-14 weeks scan) are:
    • Acrania/ Anencephaly
    • Encephalocele
    • Alobar holoprosencephaly
    • Iniencephaly
    • Exomphalos
    • Gastroschisis
    • Body-Stalk anomaly
    • Megacystis
    • Missing Limbs

 

Ref: Page No 186, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Double decidual sac sign

questions.text: The first structure to appear in an intrauterine gestational sac on ultrasound is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Yolk sac

 

Explanation

 

The yolk sac is the first anatomical structure to appear in an intra-uterine gestational sac. It appears on a TVS at 5.5 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Cardiac activity in the fetal pole is seen at 6 weeks in TVS or at 7 weeks on a transabdominal scan (TAS)

 

Option B: This is a sign seen in early pregnancy on ultrasound at about 6 weeks

 

Option C: Embryo: Or fetal pole: This is seen on the TVS at 6 weeks (7 weeks on TAS)

 

Educational Objective:

 

About the Yolk sac:

 

  • 1st anatomical structure identified within the g sac (5 weeks)
  • Undetectable after 10 weeks
    • Large yolk sac: (≥ 6mm) is associated with poor obstetrical outcome

 

Other important points:

 

  • On a Transvaginal Sonogram (TVS):
    • The gestational sac appears at 5 weeks
    • Yolk sac at 5.5 weeks
    • Embryo with cardiac activity at 6 weeks
       
  • On Transabdominal sonography these appear 1 week later

 

Ref: Page no 186, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Identify the condition as shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior Placenta Previa 

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is an Obstetric ultrasound showing the lower uterine segment with the bladder anteriorly. The cervix is seen and the placenta is seen posteriorly (as it is opposite to the bladder). It is seen to partially cover the os. So, this is Post placenta previa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placenta previa is classified as follows: (obsolete)

 

 

Type 1 ---Mild degree ----- Type 2     Type 3--- Major degree ----- Type 4

 

Type 1: Low lying:  implantation in lower uterine segment but not touching the os.

 

Type 2: Marginal: placenta is at the edge of the os but not covering it

 

Type 3: Partial Placenta Previa: Placenta partially covering the internal os.

 

Type 4: Complete Placenta Previa: Placenta completely covering the internal os.

 

  • Placenta previa can also be classified on USG as (Newer system)
    • True placenta previa : the placenta covers the internal os either partially or completely
    • Low lying placenta:  placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment such that the edge does not reach the os  but remains  outside a 2 cm wide  perimeter around the os.

 

Ref: Page 774, Williamâ€™s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Identify this anomaly:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anencephaly

 

Explanation

 

  • The anomaly seen is an anencephaly
  • About Anencephaly:
    • Anencephaly is the most severe form of NTD
    • Characterized by an absence of cortical tissue & absence of the cranial vault
    • Detected by USG as early as 11 weeks. 
    • Frog face appearance on ultrasound
    • Associated with polyhydramnios
    • If undiagnosed, patient may present with face or breech presentation at term

 

Other options:

 

  • Option B: Cleft lip: It is an opening in the upper lip due to failure of fusion of tissues forming it. It can occur alone or as a part of a genetic syndrome and may also have an accompanying cleft palate. Ultrasound can be best diagnosed on a 3D scan.
  • Option C: Encephalocele: It is a sac like protrusion of the brain and the membranes covering it through a opening in the skull.
  • Option D: Facial deformities are best seen on a 3D scan

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • The anomaly seen is an anencephaly
  • About Anencephaly:
    • Anencephaly is the most severe form of NTD
    • Characterized by an absence of cortical tissue & absence of the cranial vault
    • Detected by USG as early as 11 weeks. 
    • Frog face appearance on ultrasound
    • Associated with polyhydramnios
    • If undiagnosed, patient may present with face or breech presentation at term

 

Ref: Page no 186, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 34-year primi presents at 8 weeks pregnancy, The ultrasound shows an anembryonic pregnancy. An anembryonic pregnancy is when, on ultrasound, the embryo is not seen at a Mean Sac Diameter (MSD) of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. ≥ 25mm

 

Explanation:

 

  • Absence of an embryo at a MSD ≥ 25 mm – anembryonic pregnancy
  • Absence of Cardiac activity at a CRL ≥ 7 mm – non-viable pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Absence of an embryo at a MSD ≥ 25 mm – anembryonic pregnancy
  • Absence of Cardiac activity at a CRL ≥ 7 mm – non-viable pregnancy

 

Ref: Page no 186, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: On ultrasound, a non-viable pregnancy refers to one in which the cardiac activity has not appeared even when the embryo is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. ≥ 7 mm

 

Explanation

 

  • Absence of an embryo at a MSD ≥ 25 mm – anembryonic pregnancy
  • Absence of Cardiac activity at a CRL ≥ 7 mm – non-viable pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Absence of an embryo at a MSD ≥ 25 mm – anembryonic pregnancy
  • Absence of Cardiac activity at a CRL ≥ 7 mm – non-viable pregnancy

 

Ref: Page no 186, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Crown – Rump length

questions.text: The best measurement for estimating gestational age on ultrasound is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Crown-Rump Length

 

Explanation

 

  • CRL: This is the Crown-Rump Length and is the most accurate method to establish and confirm the gestational age

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Biparietal diameter (BPD): The BPD is a measurement of the fetus done after 14 weeks. It is the most accurate estimation of gestational age after 14 weeks.
  • Option C: Head circumference: The HC is a measurement done after 14 weeks
  • Option D: Femur length is also a fetal biometric measurement done after 14 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

About Crown Rump Length (CRL)

 

  • Most accurate method to establish/ confirm gestational age
  • It is measured in the mid – sagittal plane
  • Embryo in neutral position
  • Till 13 weeks: accuracy of 5 – 7 days
  • In the 2nd trimester the best parameter to estimate gestational age in:  BPD
  • If dolichocephaly/ brachycephaly; HC better
  • Abdominal Circumference (AC): greatest variation

 

Ref: Page no 159, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: What measurement is being shown in this image on ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. CRL

 

  • The measurement seen is the crown rump length (CRL)

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRL:

  • Most accurate method to establish/ confirm gestational age
  • It is measured in the mid – sagittal plane
  • Embryo in neutral position
  • Till 13 weeks: accuracy of 5 – 7 days

 

Ref: Page no 159, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Abnormal flow in the ductus venosus
Absent nasal bone
Increased nuchal translucency

questions.text: All the following are ultrasound features of a Down Syndrome fetus seen at 11-14 weeks scan except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Limb hypoplasia

 

Explanation:

 

The features seen on an 11-14 weeks ultrasound of a Down syndrome fetus are:

 

  1. Increased NT
  2. Absent nasal bone
  3. Abnormal flow in the ductus venosus
  4. Tricuspid regurgitation
    • Limb hypoplasia is not a feature of Down syndrome on 11-14 weeks ultrasound

 

Educational Objective:

 

The features seen on an 11-14 weeks ultrasound of a Down syndrome fetus are:

 

  1. Increased NT
  2. Absent nasal bone
  3. Abnormal flow in the ductus venosus
  4. Tricuspid regurgitation

 

Ref: Page no 282; William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia can be diagnosed on fetal ultrasound at the following gestational age?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 15 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia can be diagnosed as early 15 weeks

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Diaphragmatic hernia:

 

  • Defect in the diaphragm through which abdominal organs herniate into the thorax.
  • Left sided: 75% cases
  • Can be detected as early as 14-15 weeks but some may be undetected till the 3rd trimester
  • Always look for associated cardiovascular anomalies
  • Amenable to fetal therapy: FETO (Fetal endoscopic tracheal occlusion)

 

Ref: Page no 198, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: This is an image of an ultrasound in twin pregnancy. What is the chorionicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dichorionic Diamniotic

 

Explanation:

  • In this image we can see the lambda or the twin peak sign which is seen in Dichorionic Diamniotic Twins

Other Options

  • Option B: Dichorionic Monoamniotic: There is no such type of twin
  • Option C: Monochorionic Diamniotic: This is a type of monzygotic twinning wherein on ultrasound, an inverted "T" sign will be seen
  • Option D: Monochorionic Monoamniotic: This is a type of monozygotic twinning in whch there is a single chorion and amnion and there will not be any inter-twin membrane visible on the ultrasound

Educational Objective:

 

Determination of chorionicity in twin pregnancy:

 

  • Determined best by ultrasound in the 1st trimester (8- 10 weeks)
  • Twin peak sign (Lambda sign) – Dichorionic Diamniotic Twins
  • Inverted T sign – Monochorionic Diamniotic
  • No intervening membrane in Monochorionic Monoamniotic Twins

 

 

Ref: Page 870, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Size of placenta

questions.text: What is being measured in this obstetric ultrasound image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amniotic Fluid

 

Explanation:

 

Amniotic fluid appears hypoechoic on ultrasound and is as measured in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B: Cervical length

 

 

  • Option C: Size of placenta:

 

 

  • Option D:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amniotic fluid is measured on ultrasound by 2 methods

 

  1. Deepest vertical pocket (2 – 8 cm)
  2. Amniotic Fluid Index (8 – 24 cm) – the liquor in 4 quadrants are measured and added up.

 

Ref: Page 188, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Gestational Diabetes mellitus
Patient on Lithium therapy
Previous baby with VSD

questions.text: All are indications for a fetal ECHO except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gestational Diabetes mellitus

 

Explanation:

 

  • In gestational diabetes mellitus, there is no additional risk of congenital anomalies, so an ECHO is not required. Only in overt diabetes, there is an increased risk of congenital anomalies, especially cardiovascular anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The following are indications for doing a fetal ECHO

 

  1. Suspected fetal cardiac anomaly
  2. Extracardiac anomaly in the fetus
  3. Fetal chromosomal anomaly
  4. Fetal arrythmia
  5. Fetal Hydrops
  6. Thick NT
  7. Previous baby with Congenital heart disease (CHD)
  8. Either parent with CHD
  9. Conception through IVF
  10. Maternal anti Ro/ anti La (Congenital heart blocks )
  11. Exposure to Lithium (Ebsteins anomaly) / Anti-epileptic drugs/other teratogenic drugs
  12. Pregestational DM/ Overt diabetes
  13. Phenylketonuria (associated with co-arctation of aorta, hypoplastic left heart)

 

Ref: Page no 201, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Suspected Adherent placenta
Maternal pelvic mass
Fetal anatomic survey

questions.text: Magnetic Resonance Imaging is used in obstetrics in all these situations except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Contracted pelvis

 

Explanation:

 

MRI is not useful in diagnosing contracted pelvis. Contracted pelvis is best diagnosed by clinical pelvimetry. Actually, the best test of a pelvis is the fetal head itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI in pregnancy:

 

  • MRI is safe in pregnancy
  • Due to cost and as it is not portable and time consuming, its role is limited
  • Benefit in
    • Adjunct to USG in fetal anatomic survey
    • Placental invasion
    • Maternal pelvic masses

 

Ref: Page no 215, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 2D ultrasound
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Doppler ultrasound
3D ultrasound

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman with a history of type 1 diabetes is concerned about fetal well-being. Which fetal imaging modality is commonly used to assess placental and fetal blood flow, as well as fetal oxygenation during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Doppler ultrasound

 

Explanation:

 

  • Doppler ultrasound is commonly used to assess placental and fetal blood flow, as well as fetal oxygenation during pregnancy.
  • This imaging modality can help monitor fetal well-being, especially in high-risk pregnancies.

 

Other Options

 

  • Option A: 2D ultrasound is routinely used for all ANC patients. This tells us
    • No of fetuses
    • Placental position
    • Growth parameters: BPD, HC, AC and FL
    • Amniotic fluid volume
    • Fetal anomalies
    • Adnexal lesions
       
  • Option B: MRI is useful for specific indications such as Adjunct to USG in fetal anatomic survey, placental invasion or maternal pelvic masses.
  • Option D: 3D USG is useful in detecting surface anomalies in the fetus like cleft lip. It is alwso very helpful in diagnosing Mullerian anomalies

 

Educational Objective: An Obstetric Doppler is useful in:

 

  • Seeing the flow in uterine arteries (Screening for preeclampsia)
  • Flow in the umbilical artery in IUGR, utero-placental insufficiency and antepartum fetal monitoring in high risk pregnancies
  • Flow in the middle cerebral artery (IUGR, Rh isoimmunized fetuses)
  • Screening of Down syndrome at 11-14 weeks (Tricuspid regurgitation, Abnormal ductus venosus)

 

Reference:  William’s textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition page 213-214

choices.text: Transabdominal ultrasound
Color Doppler ultrasound

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman presents for a fetal ultrasound at 7 weeks of gestation. What is the most appropriate type of ultrasound for dating the pregnancy accurately?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Transvaginal ultrasound

 

Explanation:

 

  • Transvaginal ultrasound is the most appropriate type of ultrasound for dating the pregnancy accurately in the first trimester. It provides better resolution and access to the developing embryo. The CRL is most accurate for estimation of age in the first trimester.

 

Other Options

 

  • Option A: Transabdominal ultrasound: Is usually preferred after 12 weeks in pregnancy as the uterus is an abdominal organ after 12 weeks.
  • Option B: 3D USG is useful in detecting surface anomalies in the fetus like cleft lip. It is alwso very helpful in diagnosing Mullerian anomalies
  • Option D: Doppler ultrasound is commonly used to assess placental and fetal blood flow, as well as fetal oxygenation during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A transvaginal scan (TVS) is preferred over a transabdominal scan (TAS) in the 1st trimester
  • A CRL done between 8 to 12 weeks is the best determinant of gestational age
  • In a 1st trimester scan, the following structures are seen.

 

 

Reference: Williams textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition page  183.

choices.text: To assess for neural tube defects
To evaluate fetal growth and anatomy
To estimate amniotic fluid volume
To check for placental abnormalities

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester presents for a routine prenatal ultrasound. What is the primary purpose of this mid-pregnancy ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. To evaluate fetal growth and anatomy

 

Explanation:

 

  • The primary purpose of a mid-pregnancy ultrasound (typically performed between 18-22 weeks) is to evaluate fetal growth and anatomy, including assessing the development of various organs and structures in the fetus. This scan may also be referred to as anomaly scan/ malformation scan/ Targeted imaging for fetal anomaly (TIFFA scan)

 

Educational Objective: Routine ultrasounds done in pregnancy include

 

  1. 1st trimester (6-10 weeks): For confirmation of pregnancy, excluding ectopic pregnancy, number of fetuses, viability, adnexal lesions
  2. 11-14 weeks: Level 1 scan: For Down syndrome screening and uterine artery doppler for preeclampsia screening
  3. 18-22 weeks: TIFFA scan (Targeted imaging for fetal anomaly)
  4. > 28 weeks: Fetal growth and well being, placental localization, amniotic fluid volume, confirming presentation.

 

Reference: Williams textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition page 187
